Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract

Award: DMS 1309340, Principal Investigator: Anton Petrunin

The principal investigator proposes to continue the study of Alexandrov geometry and its applications, which include isometric group actions and Riemannian geometry. The research is divided into the following main parts: (1) Finding new examples of CAT[0] spaces, related to isometric actions on Euclidean space, (2) Collapsing and convergence of Riemannian manifolds, and (3) Pure Alexandrov geometry.

Alexandrov geometry studies metric spaces from an axiomatic point of view, which is similar to the approach given in Euclid's Elements. This theory has applications in many branches of modern geometry. In addition to to the pure research, the principal investigator proposes to continue his work with co-authors on a book which is intended to be a comprehensive text and reference in this area of geometry; he also has two other smaller projects oriented to geometric education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
• Jointly with Nina Lebedava, we gave a bound on the total curvature of a minimizing geodesic on a convex surface. The question was open for more than 15 years.
  • Jointly with Dmitri Panov we prove and study a convexity type property on maximal open flat subset in a Riemannian manifolds with nonnegative/nonpositive curvature.
  • Jointly with N. Lebedeva, V Matveev, and V. Shevchishin, we prove that any 3-dimensional polyhedral space with nonnegative curvature can be approximated by of 3-dimensional Riemannian orbifolds with nonnegative sectional curvature.
  • We proved a globalization for non-complete but geodesic spaces.
  • Jointly with S. Stadler, we prove an analog of Schoen--Yau univalentness theorem for saddle maps between discs.
  • Jointly with Alexander Lytchak and Vitali Kapovitch, we introduce and study a metric-measure analog of boundary for metric space.

 

Broader Impacts

Jointly with Allan Yashinski we wrote notes
based on my lectures. These lectures were a part of the geometry course held during the Mathematics Advanced Study Semesters (MASS) Program at Penn State. The lectures are meant to be accessible to advanced undergraduate and early graduate students in mathematics.

We have placed a great emphasis on clarity and exposition.
The lectures might be considered as an elementary and entraining introduction to h-principle. The topics include Zalgaller's folding theorem,  Brehm's extension theorem,  Akopyan's approximation theorem,Arnold's  problem on paper folding
and Gromov's rumpling theorem on existence of length preserving maps from surface to the plane.

Jointly with S. Alexander and V. Kapovitch we wrote lecture notes based on lectures given at the Summer School, Summer 2016 in Yaroslavl.
These lectures are oriented toward to undergraduate students and suppose to give a very soft introduction to Alexandrov geometry with minimum preliminaries and meaningful applications.
